text: - [Director] Right, on take one.
(dramatic music)
(cars zooming)

- Covering Formula One is
tricky. It's very complex.

There's multiple things
happening simultaneously
over a large real estate.
It is really difficult sometimes
to get all that information over

to the fan without
bombarding them as well.
So it's gotta be very intuitive,

and they've gotta come
along into that journey
with the data and with the graphics.

- So AWS shadowed the F1 broadcast
team as an event in 2022,
the Belgian Grand Prix.
We observed that they
were using many different visual sources

to help them direct
the show of Formula One
that we, at home, enjoy.

We determined that we could
consolidate those visual views
into a sort of dashboard environment

that would make it easier
for them to do their job,
but then also listen to the data signals,

and find ways to provide
proactive insights

to the broadcast production
team to help them, you know,
create the best show that's possible.
So Track Pulse takes advantage of the data
that we get from Formula One as a sport.
You know, these cars generate more
than a million data points a second,

and so the volume and
complexity of that data is rife.

So taking advantage of technology,
artificial intelligence
to gain insights from that data

is really what Track
Pulse is meant to achieve.

And instead of fully relying
on the human capability
within Formula One's broadcast team,

we are augmenting that with
artificial intelligence,

such that they can do
the optimum job they do

in broadcasting and using
the signals from the data
to help them do that.

- There's real tangible benefits
into having Track Pulse.

It really helps us predict
what's going to happen,
and then what we then need
to build into the coverage for that.

It is predicting what
might happen in five laps,

or what part of the story we
need to get across earlier on,

and therefore, then we
can bring that to the fan,
and connect to the fan so much better.

Track Pulse is a mechanism
that we can take all the data

that we have, but also the
analytics of that data as well,

that we already do with AWS,
and really creating stories.

So, you know, it's a real
mix covering Formula One.
You have to be part storyteller,
part Formula One strategist in a way.

It's very hard to find
someone who could do both.

So actually enabling them
to have all the information
at their fingertips to look at it,

then brief the directors of
where the coverage should be,
and how it should shape up.

- With the vast amount
of data that's produced
by Formula One as a sport,

using AWS technology to help
distill that data into stories
that the global fan base can understand

is really an intrinsic
part of the partnership
between these organizations.
